contentrichtext.text: '''Baron Oranmore and Browne''', of Carrabrowne Castle in the County of Galway and of Castle Macgarrett in the County of Mayo, is a title in the [[Peerage of Ireland]]. It was created in 1836 for [[Dominick Browne, 1st Baron Oranmore and Browne|Dominick Browne]], who had earlier represented [[Mayo (UK Parliament constituency)|County Mayo]] in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]]. His son, the second Baron, sat in the [[House of Lords]] as an [[Representative peer|Irish Representative Peer]] from 1869 to 1900. Lord Oranmore and Browne assumed the surname of Guthrie on his marriage in 1859 to Christina Guthrie. He was succeeded by his son, the third Baron. He was an Irish Representative Peer from 1902 to 1926 and a member of the short-lived [[Senate of Southern Ireland]]. In 1926 he was created '''Baron Mereworth''', of [[Mereworth Castle]] in the County of Kent, in the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom]]. This title gave the barons an automatic seat in the House of Lords until the passing of the [[House of Lords Act 1999]]. On his death in 1927 the title passed to his son, the fourth Baron. He married, as his third wife, the actress [[Sally Gray]]. Lord Oranmore and Browne died in August 2002, aged 100 years and 291 days. He was thereby the third oldest [[hereditary peer]] ever. He was succeeded by his son, Dominick, from his first marriage, the fifth and ({{as of|2010}}) present holder of the titles. In May 2011, Mereworth went to court to attempt to force the House of Lords to issue him a [[Hereditary peer#Writs of summons|Writ of Summons]] allowing him to sit and vote in the House by virtue of the [[Letters Patent]] issued in the creation of the barony. The case (Baron Mereworth v Ministry of Justice) was dismissed on the grounds that the High Court did not have jurisdiction on how the House of Lords conducted its business. Furthermore, even if the court did have jurisdiction, the House of Lords act of 1999 clearly withdrew the right of holders of Letters Patent to be issued a Writ of Summons purely "by virtue" of those Letters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cases.iclr.co.uk/Subscr/search.aspx?path=WLR%20Dailies/WLRD%202011/wlrd2011-217 |title=Mereworth v Ministry of Justice (2011) EWHC 1589 (Ch); (2011) WLR (D) 2 |publisher=The Incorporated Council of Law Reporting for England & Wales |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> Mereworth was also ordered to pay £8,800 in costs. This case was referenced as precedent in the official rebuttal of a claim by [[Viscount Monckton]] that he was entitled to claim membership of the House of Lords.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.uk/business/news/2011/july/letter-to-viscount-monckton/ |title=A letter to Viscount Monckton of Brenchley from the Clerk of the Parliaments |publisher=United Kingdom Parliament |date=11 July 2011 |accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> ==Barons Oranmore and Browne (1836)== *[[Dominick Browne, 1st Baron Oranmore and Browne]] (1787–1860) *[[Geoffrey Guthrie-Browne, 2nd Baron Oranmore and Browne|Geoffrey Dominick Augustus Frederick Guthrie-Browne, 2nd Baron Oranmore and Browne]] (1819–1900) *[[Geoffrey Browne, 3rd Baron Oranmore and Browne|Geoffrey Henry Browne, 3rd Baron Oranmore and Browne]] (1861–1927) *[[Dominick Browne, 4th Baron Oranmore and Browne|Dominick Geoffrey Edward Browne, 4th Baron Oranmore and Browne]] (1901–2002) *[[Dominick Browne, 5th Baron Oranmore and Browne|Dominick Geoffrey Thomas Browne, 5th Baron Oranmore and Browne]] (b. 1929) The [[heir presumptive]] is the present holder's nephew Shaun Dominick Browne (b. 1964). ==Notes== {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{reflist}} ==References== *Kidd, Charles, Williamson, David (editors). ''Debrett's Peerage and Baronetage'' (1990 edition). New York: St Martin's Press, 1990, {{Page needed |date=February 2013}} *[http://www.leighrayment.com/peers/peersO.htm Leigh Rayment's Peerage Page] {{Irish barons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oranmore And Browne}} [[Category:Baronies in the Peerage of Ireland]]
